question: Which of these is NOT the correctly stated component of the expenditure method of measuring national income ? SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Export plus import expenditure. Formula for calculating National income by expenditure method, GDP = C + I + G + (X −M) Where, C : Consumption expenditure (household spending on goods and services). I : Investment expenditure (business spending on capital goods). G : Government expenditure (spending on infrastructure, salaries, etc.). X — M : Net exports (exports minus imports).

question: ________ is the income of the Government, which arises out of the property left by the people without a legal heir. SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Escheat. Felony - Felonies are the most serious offences that a person or corporation can commit against another. Moot - Unsettled, open to argument or debatable. Lien - A legal claim or legal right which is made against the assets that are held as collaterals for satisfying a debt.

question: The stabilisation function of the government budget mainly includes ____. SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (2nd shift)

options.B: intervention to expand or reduce the
options.D: distribution of income in society in a

solution.correct_answer: B. intervention to expand or reduce the
solution.explanation: Stabilisation policy seeks to limit erratic swings in the economy's total output (measured by the Gross domestic product), Controlling surges in inflation or deflation. Two forms : Expansionary policy - Government moves to lower taxes or increase spending to boost the economy. Contractionary policy - When the Government increases taxes or reduces spending to slow the economy and reduce inflation.

question: Which of the following items is NOT a part of the non-plan revenue expenditure of the government budget ? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.correct_answer: D. Central assistance for states and
solution.explanation: The distinction between Plan and Non-Plan expenditure was abolished in 2016 on the recommendation of C. R. Rangarajan Committee. Non-Plan Revenue Expenditure refers to the recurring expenses incurred by the government that are not associated with any specific development plan or project. Examples include Interest Payments, Salaries and Wages, Subsidies, Pensions, Defense Revenue Expenditure, Other Administrative Expenses, etc.

question: In the estimation of national income, which of the following items will be subtracted from NNP at market price? SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (1st shift)

options.B: Net product taxes and net production

solution.explanation: Net indirect taxes: Net National Product (NNP) at factor cost is also known as national income. NNP at Factor Cost = NNP at Market Price — Net Indirect Taxes. Thus, Net Indirect Taxes must be subtracted from NNP at Market Price to arrive at National Income (NNP at Factor Cost).

question: Proportional taxes would help to reduce the autonomous expenditure multiplier because _____________ . SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (1st shift)

options.B: MPC does not have any role in it

solution.explanation: Taxes reduce the MPC. MPC (marginal propensity to consume) - It is the change in consumption per unit change in income. Proportional taxes take a constant fraction of income as tax, reducing the disposable income available for consumption. Since households have less disposable income after taxes, the amount they consume from additional income decreases. Thus, the autonomous expenditure multiplier will reduce.

question: CBIC stands for ________. SSC CHSL 09/08/2023 (3rd shift)

options.B: Central Board on Issues Related to
options.D: Central Board of Indirect Taxes and

solution.correct_answer: D. Central Board of Indirect Taxes and
solution.explanation: Central Board of Indirect Taxes and Customs (erstwhile Central Board of Excise and Customs). It is one of the Boards constituted under the

question: Which country first introduced zero-based budgeting? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: The U.S. Zero based budgeting (ZBB) : A method of budgeting in which all expenses are evaluated each time a Budget is made and expenses must be justified for each new period. It was introduced by Peter Pyhrr in 1970’s. In India, the ZBB was introduced in the department of science and technology in 1983, and adopted by the Indian Government in 1986. It was promoted during the Seventh Five-Year Plan. In India, Maharashtra is the first state to implement Zero-based budgeting.

question: Match List I with List II and choose your answer from the code below: List - I List - II i. Service tax a. Capital receipt ii. Interest receipt b. Revenue expenditure iii. Sale of shares of PSUs c. Non-tax revenue iv. Salaries and pension d. Tax revenue SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: i-d, ii-c, iii-a, iv-b. Tax revenue: Income tax, corporate tax, customs duties, VAT, etc. Non-tax revenue: Interest on loans provided by the government, dividends from public sector enterprises, fees for services, etc. Capital receipt: Borrowing from the public, sale of government assets, disinvestment of shares in PSUs, etc. Revenue expenditure: Spending on government salaries, pensions, subsidies, interest payments on loans, etc.

question: Which of the following is NOT included in 'Operating Surplus' ? SSC CHSL 10/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Wages in Cash. Operating Surplus : Concept used in national accounts statistics which refers to the measure of surplus accruing from production of the output before deducting property income from it like profits, rent, and interest. It is a component of value added and gross domestic product.

question: What is the basic difference in the aggregates at market price and factor cost ? SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Net indirect taxes. Factor cost - The total cost of all the factors of production in manufacturing a good, which does not account for the subsidies received and taxes paid.

question: Identify the correct match. A) Pension to retired government employees - Revenue Receipt B) Purchase of Machinery in Railways - Capital Expenditure SSC CHSL 11/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Only B. Capital expenditure : Expenditure that either creates an asset or reduces the liability of the government. Example : Purchases of property, equipment, land, computers, furniture, and software.

question: Exports of mangoes by India is a part of _____ method of measurement of its national income. SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Expenditure. This method adds up Consumer spending, Investment, Government expenditure, and Net exports. Formula (Expenditure method for national income): C + I + G + (X - M), where C = Consumer spending, I = Investment, G = Government spending, X = Exports and M = Imports.

question: When did the Government of India bring the gender sensitivities of the budgetary allocation in its statement for the first time ? SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 2005-06. India introduced Gender-Responsive Budgeting (GRB) to design public spending in a way that ensures that the benefits accrue as much to the country's women as they do to the men.

question: ____is an item for which both, GST and central excise duty are applicable in India. SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Tobacco and tobacco products. GST (Goods and Services Tax) : Implemented - 1st July 2017. Amendment - 101st Amendment Act, 2016. Article - 279 A. The primary GST slabs for any regular taxpayers are presently pegged at 0% (nil-rated), 5%, 12%, 18% & 28%. However, petroleum products, alcoholic drinks, and electricity are not taxed under GST and instead are taxed separately by the individual state governments.

question: While computing Net Economic Welfare (NEW), which of the following items is subtracted from GNP ? SSC CHSL 14/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. Adjustments for congestion of urban
solution.explanation: Net Economic Welfare (NEW) : It is a broader concept than Gross National Product (GNP) to measure economic welfare. NEW = GNP + Value of Housewives Services + Value of leisure – Expenditure on defence – Cost of Environment Degradation.

question: Revenue expenditure minus revenue receipts is _________. SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Revenue deficit refers to the excess of revenue expenditure over revenue income in a financial year. Budget Deficit = Total Expenditures by the government – Total Income of the government.

question: Which of the following statements is/are FALSE ? A) The impact of externality is always positive. B) Real national income means national income at constant prices SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Only A. Externalities refer to the positive or negative effects of an economic activity on third parties who

question: Which of the following is an example of direct tax? SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Income Tax. It is a type of tax governments impose on income generated by businesses and individuals within their jurisdiction.

question: GDP deflator = _______ SSC CGL 18/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: (Nominal GDP / Real GDP) × 100. The GDP deflator also known as implicit price deflator is an indicator of inflation. This helps in measuring the actual increase in GDP.

question: In which union budget was India's first sovereign wealth fund named 'National Investment and Infrastructure Fund (NIIF)' announced ? SSC CGL 20/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: 2015-16. NIIF is a government-backed entity established to provide long-term capital to the country’s infrastructure sector. Headquarter - Mumbai. The Budget Division of the Department of Economic Affairs in the Finance Ministry is the nodal body responsible for preparing the Budget.

question: ____expenditure and ____ receipts are shown by the government budget. SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Estimated; estimated. Budget {Annual Financial Statement (Article 112)} - A statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the Government in a financial year. It contains Estimates of revenue and capital receipts, ways and means to raise the revenue, details of the actual receipts and expenditure of the closing financial year with reasons for any deficit or surplus in that year, the economic and financial policy of the coming year (taxation proposals, prospects of revenue, spending programme and introduction of new schemes).

question: Which of the following is NOT an example of factor payment? SSC CGL 26/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Pension. Factor payments : It is the sum total of remunerations earned by the four factors of production. Rent is paid for land. Wages are paid for labour. Interest is paid for capital. Profit is the payment for entrepreneurship.

question: In national income accounting, GVA stands for SSC MTS 04/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Gross value added (GVA) - A significant macroeconomic indicator that measures the value of goods and services produced in an economy, after deducting the cost of inputs and raw materials used in the production process. Gross Value Added = GDP + subsidies on products - taxes on products.

question: Duties levied on goods produced within the country are _______. SSC MTS 12/05/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Excise taxes. Custom duties - It is a tax collected on imports and exports by the customs authorities of a country. Anti - dumping duty is a tariff imposed on imports manufactured in foreign countries that are priced below the fair market value of similar goods in the domestic market.

question: If the value of gross fiscal deficit will be more than net interest liabilities, the value of gross primary deficit will be ___________ . SSC MTS 20/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Positive. Gross primary Deficit = Gross fiscal Deficit - Net interest liabilities. Deficit - The amount by which the spending done in a budget surpasses the earnings.

question: When was the Direct Tax Code Bill introduced in the Parliament of India? SSC CHSL 10/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 2010. Direct tax: It is directly paid to the authority imposing the tax. It is levied on taxable income earned by individuals and corporate entities. Example - Income tax, real property tax, personal property tax, and taxes on assets, corporation tax, gift tax, inheritance tax.

question: If there are N firms in the economy, each assigned with a serial number from 1 to N, then as per the product method, GDP can be written as _____ . SSC CHSL 21/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: + ..... + . 𝐺𝑉𝐴1 𝐺𝑉𝐴2 𝐺𝑉𝐴𝑁 Value added or product method ( + 𝐺𝑉𝐴1 ..... + ), where GVA represents 𝐺𝑉𝐴2 𝐺𝑉𝐴𝑁 gross value added by the firms. The Value Added Method (Product method) : In the product method we calculate the aggregate annual value of goods and services produced. The value added of a firm is, value of production of the firm – value of intermediate goods used by the firm.

question: Assume that the exchange rate between the US Dollar and Indian Rupee is $1 = 55. Now if this exchange rate increases to $1 = ₹60, then in this case the Indian Rupee has _____in comparison to the US dollar. SSC CGL Tier II (07/03/2023)

solution.explanation: Depreciated. Currency Depreciation - The loss of value of a country's currency with respect to one or more foreign reference currencies.

question: The subject of the Study of Macroeconomics is based on which principle? SSC CGL 05/12/2022 (1st Shift) www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Economics

solution.correct_answer: A. The principle of National Income
solution.explanation: The principle of National Income. Macroeconomics - It explains how the economy as a whole operates and how aggregate demand and supply are used to generate the level of national income and employment.

question: Which of the following organisations of the Government of India has been reporting the GDP at factor cost and at market prices? SSC CGL 08/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: National Statistical Office. It also compiles the Index of Industrial Production (IIP), Annual Survey of Industries (ASI) and all-India Economic Censuses. It conducts nationwide sample surveys to gather data on employment, consumer expenditure, housing conditions, environment, literacy, health, nutrition, and family welfare. The National Sample Survey Office (NSSO, founded in 1950) is merged with the Central Statistical Office (CSO, founded in 1951) under the Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation to form the National Statistical Office (NSO) in 2019.

question: Which type of tax acts as an automatic stabiliser in the economy? SSC CGL 09/12/2022 (4th Shift)

solution.explanation: Proportional income tax. The proportional income tax acts as an automatic stabiliser – a shock absorber because it makes disposable income, and thus consumer spending, less sensitive to fluctuations in GDP. When GDP rises, income taxes reduce disposable income, limiting excessive spending. During recession, income falls less sharply, and consumption does not drop as much as it, because tax liability has been fixed.

question: Who among the following headed the National Income Committee? SSC CGL 12/12/2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: PC Mahalanobis (chairman of Indian Statistical Institute). The National Income Committee (NIC) (1949) calculated the National Income of India and compiled statistics. Members of NIC : VKRV Rao and DR Gadgil.

question: The difference between a farmer's output over and above his on-farm consumption is known as ______. SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Marketable Surplus. Consumer surplus occurs when the price consumers pay for a product or service is less than the price they are willing to pay. Domestic consumption products and services that are bought and used in the country that makes them.

question: In 1950-51, what percentage of GDP of India was contributed by the industrial sector ? SSC CPO 10/11/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: 13%. In 1950-51, the Agriculture sector contributed 59% to India’s GDP, and the Service sector contributed 28% to India’s GDP.

question: Which of the following commodities are exempted from GST ? SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Alcohol for human consumption. Other Goods not covered under Goods and Services Tax (GST) : Petrol, high-speed diesel, aviation turbine fuel, crude oil, Electricity, and Natural Gas.

question: GDP that takes into account the costs in terms of environmental pollution and exploitation of natural resources is called __________. SSC CHSL 27/05/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: green GDP. The Green Gross Domestic Product is an indicator of economic growth with environmental factors taken into consideration along with the standard GDP of a country.

question: Which of the following angles of the flow of factor payments forms the basis to estimate the national income? SSC CHSL 30/05/2022 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Income distribution angle National income is the sum of all the factor income (Wage, Rent, Interest, Profit) that is generated during a production year.

question: Which of the following statements is/are correct ? I. Only marketed goods are considered while estimating Gross Domestic Product (GDP). II. The work done by a woman at her home is outside the purview of Gross Domestic Product. III. In estimating GDP, only final goods and services are considered. SSC CGL 11/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: I, II and III. GDP is the value of all final goods and services produced within a country during a particular year. Unpaid domestic work, like cooking or caregiving at home, is valuable but not included in GDP because it is not traded in markets.

question: The value of the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) of India is published by PIB in ______. SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Indian Rupee. The GDP of India is typically measured and published in Indian Rupees, as it is the official currency of the country.

question: ______ is a tax system that collects a greater share of income from those with high incomes than from those with lower incomes. SSC CGL 12/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Progressive tax is a tax system that collects a greater share of income from those with high incomes than from those with lower incomes. Payroll tax can be defined as the tax that is withheld, charged, or levied on the payroll of the employer.

question: According to the Output Method, GDP is calculated as: SSC CGL 13/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.correct_answer: A. GDP at Constant Prices – Taxes +
solution.explanation: GDP at Constant Prices – Taxes + Subsidies. The output method is also known as the value-added method.

question: Which of the given statements about the Union Budget is/are true? a) Vote on Account deals only with the expenditure side of the government budget. b) Vote on Account and Interim Budget are not the same. c) An Interim Budget gives a complete financial statement, similar to a full budget. SSC CGL 21/04/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Budget (Annual financial statement, Article 112) is a statement of the estimated receipts and expenditure of the government in a financial year (1st April - 31st March). A vote-on-account is Parliament's approval to the Centre for withdrawal of money from the Consolidated Fund of India for a specified expenditure to be incurred for a particular period. The Union Budget 2021-22, presented by Finance Minister Nirmala Sitharaman, was India's first paperless budget. Money Banking and Financial Institutions

question: Which of the following statements regarding the functions of money is/are correct ? 1. Money as a unit of account means that it is a standard numerical unit of measurement of the market value of goods, services and other transactions. 2. Money as a standard of deferred payment is not an important function because modern economies rarely use money for future payments. SSC CHSL Tier II 18/11/2024

solution.explanation: Only 1. Money as a standard of deferred payments means that money acts as a standard for payments which are to be made in future. Functions of Money: Medium of exchange - Money is used to buy and sell goods and services. Store of value - It can be saved and used to build wealth over time. Unit of account - It is used to compare the value of different items. Basis for credit - It is used as a basis for credit.

question: Which of the following is referred to as ‘Near Money’ ? SSC MTS 18/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: National savings deposits. 'Near money' refers to assets that are not in the form of cash but can easily be converted into cash or used for transactions. National savings deposits are considered 'near money' because they can be quickly converted into cash, similar to liquid assets, though they are not immediately spendable like currency notes or coins.

question: In which year was the Shri Mahila SEWA Sahakari Bank established ? SSC MTS 05/11/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: 1974. Self-Employed Women's Association (SEWA), meaning "service" in several Indian languages, is a trade union based in Ahmedabad. Headquarters - Ahmedabad, Founder - Ela Bhatt.

question: ________is an industry association and self-regulatory organisation (SRO) whose primary objective is to work towards the robust development of the microfinance sector. SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Microfinance Institutions Network (MFIN) was established in 2009. In 2014, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) recognized MFIN as a Self-Regulatory Organization (SRO) for the NBFC-MFI, making MFIN the first industry association to be accorded recognition as an SRO by the RBI.

question: If assets of a bank are greater than liabilities, it will be recorded as: SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: net worth. The amount by which the value of the assets exceed the liabilities is the net worth (equity) of the business. The net worth reflects the amount of ownership of the business by the owners. The formula for computing net worth is : Assets - Liabilities = Net Worth.

question: Which of the following definitions best describes the concept of microfinance ? SSC CGL 11/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. Microfinance is a banking service
solution.explanation: Microfinance loans are small, unsecured loans given to low-income borrowers for starting or expanding small businesses or for basic needs like education and healthcare. The Reserve Bank of India regulates microfinance in India. Types of Microfinance Institutions (MFIs) include credit unions, NGOs, and commercial banks. Notable MFIs include Bandhan Bank, Ujjivan Small Finance Bank, Annapurna Finance, and Muthoot Microfin.

question: Which of the following institutions has contributed mainly in improving the economic status of the poor women in rural areas ? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Self-Help Groups are informal associations of people who choose to come together to find ways to improve their living conditions. They help the poor and marginalized by building skills for employment and income generation. SHGs also provide loans without requiring collateral.

question: Which of the following is a component of the SHG-bank linkage program in India? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.correct_answer: B. Banks providing loans to individual
solution.explanation: The SHG-BL Project was launched by NABARD in 1992-93, has now become the largest microfinance programme in the world. The SHG-Bank Linkage Model involves banks (Commercial, Rural, and Cooperative) directly lending to SHGs, which manage and guarantee loans for members.

question: Which of the following is Fisher's equation of exchange? SSC CGL 19/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: MV = PT. Fisher Equation states that the nominal interest rate is equal to the sum of the real interest rate plus inflation. It lies at the heart of the Quantity Theory of Money. MV = PT, where M = Money Supply, V = Velocity of circulation, P = Price Level, and T = Transactions.

question: Which of the following is a difference between self-help groups (SHGs) and microfinance institutions (MFIs) in India? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.B: SHGs provide only credit, while MFIs

solution.explanation: Self-Help Groups (SHGs) in India, started in the late 1980s by NGOs, typically consist of 10 to 20 women, serving as financial intermediaries. Examples include Amba Foundation, ASRLM, and Chamoli SHG. Microfinance institutions (MFIs), like Ujivan Financial Services and Annapurna Finance, provide banking services to low-income groups, playing a key role in poverty alleviation.

question: The Working Group under the chairmanship of_______in the year_______ proposed a new intermediate monetary aggregate to be referred to as NM2. SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Dr. YV Reddy; 1998. NM2 (Narrow Money 2) measures the money supply in an economy, including currency, demand deposits, and time deposits. It indicates liquidity and helps guide monetary policy and economic regulation. Central banks, such as the RBI, use NM2 to control inflation and manage economic growth, reflecting broader money supply aspects for policy decisions.

question: The term ‘Microfinancing’ was first used in the 1970s during the development of Grameen Bank of Bangladesh, which was founded by _____. SSC CGL 26/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Muhammad Yunus. Muhammad Yunus is a Bangladeshi economist, entrepreneur, politician, and civil society leader. He is the founder of modern micro finance. He was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize in 2006 for founding the Grameen Bank and pioneering microcredit and microfinance.

question: In 2000-01, NABARD instituted Micro Finance Development Fund with a corpus of ________. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: ₹100 crores. The Micro Finance Development Fund was established to support and promote the microfinance sector in India. The fund aimed to support microfinance institutions and promote self-help groups (SHGs) across India. NABARD (National Bank for Agriculture and Rural Development) established on 12 July 1982.

question: Which of the following is issued by commercial banks at a discount on face value? SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Certificates of deposits are unsecured, negotiable, short-term instruments in bearer form, issued by commercial banks and development financial institutions. Commercial papers - It is issued by large companies for short-term funding at lower interest rates, with maturities of 15 days to one year. Treasury bills - They are short-term government securities maturing in less than one year.

question: What is the primary aim of Regional Rural Banks in India ? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Development of rural economy. The Regional Rural Banks (RRBs): Established in 1975 under the Regional Rural Banks Act, 1976 on the recommendations of the Narsimham Committee. The first RRB was Prathama Bank, with its head office in Moradabad, Uttar Pradesh. In India, the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) oversees the entire banking system, while NABARD supervises rural financial institutions, including RRBs under the Banking Regulation Act, 1949.

question: The Central Office of the Reserve Bank of India was initially established in which present city in 1935 ? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Kolkata. Reserve Bank of India was established on 1 April 1935 on the recommendations of Hilton Young Commission. Headquarters : Mumbai, Maharashtra. Nationalization: On 1 January 1949. Currency: Issues all currency notes except for one rupee. Initially, the Central Office of the RBI was established in Calcutta but later on moved to Mumbai in 1937.

question: Which of the following refers to the purchase and sale of government securities ? SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Open market operations. The purchase and sale of government securities (G-Sec) is entrusted to the Central bank on behalf of the Government.Open market operations (OMOs) are a key tool used by central banks to control the money supply and interest rates in an economy. To increase the money supply, RBI purchases G-sec from the market and to reduce the

question: Rotating Savings and Credit Association (ROSCA) was introduced by Shirley Ardener in the year ________. SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 1964. ROSCA is an alternative financial vehicle in which a group of individuals fills the role of an informal financial institution.

question: The velocity of circulation of money will be higher when the ____is less than the requirements of the economy. SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: demand for money. It is people's desire to hold liquidity money or cash, rather than investing it in other asset forms. Money supply : It refers to the total quantity of money held by the public in various forms at any point of time in an economy. Velocity of money is a measurement of the rate at which money is exchanged in an economy. The velocity of money is typically higher in expanding economies and lower in contracting economies.

question: Which of the following banks is in charge of India’s banking and monetary system? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: RBI. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) is the central authority responsible for regulating the circulation of the Indian rupee, monetary policy, and the banking system within the Indian economy.

question: Selling of bonds by the RBI will cause money supply to __________. SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Decrease. Open Market Operations (OMOs) refer to the buying and selling of government securities by RBI to regulate the short-term money supply. If RBI wants to induce liquidity or more funds in the system, it will buy government securities and inject funds into the system. If RBI wants to reduce liquidity or money supply, it will sell securities and suck funds from the system.

question: Assume that the value of the cash reserve ratio is 25%. What will be the value of the money multiplier ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 4. The Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) - The minimum percentage of total deposits that commercial banks are required to retain as cash reserves with the RBI. This is determined by the RBI, as a limit to money or credit creation by banks. Money Multiplier = 1 𝐶𝑎𝑠ℎ 𝑅𝑒𝑠𝑒𝑟𝑣𝑒 𝑅𝑎𝑡𝑖𝑜 (𝐶𝑅𝑅) = = = 4 1 25% 1 0.25

question: What distinguishes a bank from other financial institutions? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Accepting deposits. Accepting deposits is the primary function of banks that sets them apart from other financial institutions. Banks accept deposits from the public, provide safe-keeping for these funds, and allow depositors to withdraw their money on demand. Lending and Borrowing is also a function of Banks but it is also performed by other financial institutions such as Non-Banking financial institutions (NBFC), Microfinance companies, Self-Help groups, investment firms, etc.

question: If the value / percentage of the cash reserve ratio falls, then the value of money multiplier ________. SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: rises. The money multiplier is inversely related to the cash reserve ratio (CRR). If the CRR falls, banks are required to keep a smaller percentage of their deposits as reserves. This means they can lend out more money, which increases the overall money supply. An increase in a cash reserve ratio prevents the banks from lending more money and reduces the money multiplier.

question: Who issued guidelines for the microfinance institutions in India? SSC CHSL Tier II 10/01/2024

solution.explanation: Reserve Bank of India. Microfinance institution - An organisation that offers microloans, microsavings and microinsurance services to low income populations. In India, loans below one lakh rupees are defined as microloans. The RBI defined microfinance as collateral free loans given to households having annual income up to Rs. 3 lakh.

question: When RBI decides to decrease the repo rate, money supply will _________. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: increase. Repo rate : It refers to the rate at which commercial banks borrow money by selling their securities to the Reserve bank of India (RBI) to maintain liquidity, in case of shortage of funds or due to some statutory measures. It is one of the main tools of RBI to keep inflation under control. If Repo Rate increases then money supply will decrease.

question: For providing a non-microfinance loan to a low-income household, there is a limit of ____on monthly loan repayment obligations of a household as a percentage of monthly household income. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: 50%. This limit is set by the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) to protect low-income households from over-indebtedness.

question: ________ is an instrument under the Liquidity Adjustment Facility (LAF) at which RBI lends to commercial banks. SSC Stenographer 12/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Repo rate. Reverse repo rate - The rate at which the central bank of a country borrows money from commercial banks. Bank rate - It is a rate at which the Reserve Bank of India (RBI) provides the loan to commercial banks without keeping any security. Cash reserve ratio - The percentage of a bank's total deposits that it needs to maintain as liquid cash.

question: The maximum limit on microfinance loans for NBFCs other than NBFC-MFIs is _________. SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 25% of the total assets. The Reserve Bank of India has increased the maximum limit on microfinance loans given by NBFCs that are not qualified as NBFC-MFIs to 25% from 10% earlier. RBI has also given a breather to NBFC-MFIs by reducing the minimum requirement of microfinance loans of total loan assets to 75 % from 85% earlier, in sync with the harmonisation of microfinance regulation for all lenders.

question: In the concept of money supply, M4 refers to ________. SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Afternoon)

options.D: M1+ time deposits of the public with

solution.correct_answer: C. M3+ total post office deposits
solution.explanation: M3+ total post office deposits. The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) releases data for four different metrics representing money supply, namely M1, M2, M3, and M4. M2 = M1 + Savings deposits with Post Office savings banks. M3 = M1 + Net time deposits of commercial banks.

question: Identify the correct statement in the context of money supply

solution.explanation: Only (i) and (iii). The money supply is the entire stock of currency and other liquid instruments in a country's economy as of a particular time. M1, M2, M3, M4 is the measure of money supply. M1 is the most liquid and makes transactions the easiest, while M4 is the least liquid. M1, M2 - Narrow Money. M3, M4 - Broad Money.

question: Which of the following is a function performed by commercial banks in India? SSC Stenographer 13/10/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Credit creation - Process by which commercial banks create new money by lending to businesses and individuals. Other functions of Commercial banks : Accepting deposits, Providing loans, Facilitating payments, etc. The function of Reserve bank of India includes, Issue of currency, Banking facilities to the government, Credit control, Managing foreign exchange, Issuing banking licenses.

question: In India all loans that are below _______ are considered as micro loans. SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Morning)

options.A: one lakh rupees (b) four lakh rupees
options.C: two lakh rupees (d) three lakh rupees

solution.correct_answer: A. one lakh rupees (b) four lakh rupees
solution.explanation: one lakh rupees. Non-Banking Financial Company - Micro Finance Institution (NBFC-MFI) : A type of financial institution that provides financial services, including microloans and other financial products, to low-income and economically vulnerable individuals, especially in rural and underserved areas. question: Which of the following microfinance institutions was established in India at the time of independence ? SSC CPO 03/10/2023 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Rural Cooperatives. Bandhan Bank became the first microfinance company to get a bank licence in 2014. Grameen Bank - It was the brainchild of Nobel Laureate Prof. Muhammad Yunus in Bangladesh in the 1970s.

question: Which of the following options is not an example of small savings? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Mutual Funds - A mutual fund is a type of investment vehicle consisting of a portfolio of stocks, bonds, or other securities. The mutual funds in India are regulated by the Securities and Exchange Board of India (SEBI) and the Reserve Bank of India (RBI). The Government of India set up the first mutual fund by an Act of Parliament in 1963.

question: What is the difference between a debit card and a credit card ? SSC MTS 01/09/2023 (1st Shift)

options.A: Debit cards are used for online
options.B: Credit cards require a PIN, while debit
options.D: Debit cards have higher interest rates

solution.explanation: Debit cards (Plastic Money) and credit cards look nearly identical, and both can give a fast and convenient way to pay - no matter whether you’re paying in person, online or over the phone.

question: Which of the following is NOT a characteristic of money? SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Perishability - A characteristic of products and services that do not allow for the product or service to be stored for sale at a future date. question: What is a dimension related to the sustainability of microfinance institutions in India? SSC MTS 04/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Dependency on donor funding. If an MFI heavily depends on donor funding, its operations and growth become uncertain once the donor funds dry up. Hence, reducing this dependency is crucial for the sustainability of MFIs in India.

question: What is the meaning of the term 'Collateral' in banking ? SSC MTS 08/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

options.D: An asset pledged as security for a

solution.correct_answer: D. An asset pledged as security for a
solution.explanation: Collateral is an asset that the borrower owns (such as land, building, vehicle, livestocks, deposits with banks) and uses this as a guarantee to a lender until the loan is repaid. If the borrower fails to repay the loan, the lender has the right to sell the asset or collateral to obtain payment. Property such as land titles, deposits with banks, livestock are some common examples of collateral used for borrowing.

question: What is the main source of income for commercial banks? SSC MTS 12/09/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.correct_answer: D. Interest earned on loans and
solution.explanation: The commercial bank is a financial institution whose purpose is to accept deposits from people and provide loans and other facilities. Banks collect deposits from customers and pay interest on these savings. Similarly, they charge interest when providing loans to borrowers. The primary source of a bank's income is the difference between the interest earned on loans and the interest paid on deposits. Typically, banks charge higher interest rates on loans than what they offer on deposits, creating a profit margin.

question: When the general interest rate reaches a very low level, which of the following statements will be correct SSC CHSL 02/08/2023 (1st shift)

question: Who gave the concept of 'money illusion' for the first time? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Irving Fisher (American economist) : Term ‘Money Illusion’ first coined by him in his book “Stabilising the Dollar.” Money illusion is the belief that money has a fixed value and the effects of inflation are ignored. The concept of money illusion was popularised by John Maynard Keynes. Adam Smith was a Scottish economist who wrote the book "The Wealth of Nations". Dennis Robertson was a British economist known for his work on monetary economics and his contributions to Keynesian economics.

question: Due to which of the following reasons can money be differentiated from other physical assets that can perform the function of store of value? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)

question: In which year did RBI introduce the regulatory framework for microfinance loans? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (3rd shift)

question: In any economy, the income velocity of the hoarded money (idle) by the public is equal to ______ SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (4th shift)

Formula (The velocity of money) : V = PQ / M. Where, V = Velocity of Money, PQ = Represents the GDP (Nominal Gross Domestic Product), M = Money Supply. Hoarded money - It is not used to purchase goods and services, so the income velocity of hoarded money is zero.

question: Which of the following statements is/are correct regarding liquidity trap? i. It is the point where speculative demand for money is infinitely elastic and the liquidity preference curve becomes perfectly elastic. iv. It is the point where speculative demand for money and the liquidity preference curves are not related. SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (1st shift)

options.D: Only Statements i and ii are correct

solution.correct_answer: B. Only Statement iii is correct
solution.explanation: Liquidity Trap : A situation in which prevailing market interest rates are so low that an increase in money supply has no effect on interest rates. A liquidity preference curve is a demand curve for money because a household's or business's value of liquidity is the same as its demand for cash.

question: Which of the following statements is correct ? SSC CGL 09/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

options.A: The five-year plan focuses mostly on
options.B: The five-year plan always focused on

solution.correct_answer: C. The five-year plan permits long-term
solution.explanation: The Five Year Plans were formulated, implemented and regulated by a body known as the Planning Commission. The National Development Council (NDC) was the final authority to approve Five Year Plans (FYPs). The Five-Year Plans in India were primarily focused on government intervention, not private intervention, although some plans did encourage private sector participation. It focused on the growth of all sectors depending on the needs of the economy. Five-Year Plans were not always focused on market-oriented activities.

question: Which Five-Year Plan primarily focused on the 'Garibi Hatao' initiative? SSC CGL 10/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Fifth Five-Year Plan. "Garibi Hatao" was a slogan coined by Indira Gandhi, aimed at poverty alleviation and job creation for a better life. The 5th Five Year Plan (1974-1979) had a targeted growth rate of 4.4% and achieved 4.8%. It was terminated a year early, in March 1978. The plan's final draft, prepared by D.P. Dhar, focused on eliminating poverty and achieving self-reliance.

question: The Harrod Domar model was the main idea behind the ____ Five Year Plan. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: First Five-Year Plan (1951-1956) aimed for a growth rate of 2.1% but achieved 3.6%. It focused on agriculture, investing in dams and irrigation, with significant funds allocated for the Bhakra Nangal Dam. Third Five Year Plan (1961-66) aimed to establish India as a self-reliant and self-generating economy.

question: The Drought Prone Area Programme (DPAP) for providing employment to people in drought prone areas was started by the Government of India during the _______. SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Fourth Five-Year Plan (1969 - 74): Objective - Growth with stability and progressive achievement of self-reliance. It was introduced under the Prime Ministership of Indira Gandhi. The government nationalized 14 major Indian Banks and the Green Revolution boosted agriculture. Implementation of Family Planning Programmes. The target growth rate was 5.7%, but the actual growth rate was 3.3%. Joseph Stalin was the first person to introduce a five year plan in the Soviet Union. India borrowed features of the Five-year plan from the USSR.

question: In which five-year plan was the 'food, work, and productivity' slogan used? SSC CGL 18/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Seventh Plan (1985-90): It focused on accelerating food grain production, increasing employment opportunities, and raising productivity with an emphasis on "food, work, and productivity." It was quite successful, achieving a 6% growth rate, surpassing the target of 5%, especially during a time when the 1980s were trying to overcome the so-called "Hindu Rate of Growth."

question: Which of the following statements about the second five-year plan is INCORRECT ? SSC CGL 23/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

options.D: The socialist pattern of the society

solution.explanation: The Second Five-Year Plan (1956-1961) was based on the Mahalanobis model, named after Indian statistician Prasanta Chandra Mahalanobis. The target growth rate was set at 4.5%, while the actual growth achieved was 4.3%.

question: The five-year plans for India with their duration are given below. Which of the following is correctly matched?

solution.explanation: Both a and b. The First Five-Year Plan was launched in 1951. The Second Plan (1956-1961), known as the Mahalanobis Plan, had a target growth rate of 4.5% and achieved 4.3%. The Third Plan (1961-1966) aimed to make the economy self-sufficient. Due to the Indo-China war, Indo-Pakistan war, and severe droughts, a "Plan Holiday" was observed from 1966 to 1969. The Fourth Plan (1969-1974), under Indira Gandhi, focused on growth and included Family Planning Programmes.

question: Which of the following statements are true? i. The First Five-Year Plan was based on the PC Mahalanobis model. ii. The First Five-Year Plan laid emphasis on agriculture development. iii. The Five-Year planning model in India was borrowed from Russia. SSC CHSL 03/07/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Only ii and iii. The First Five-Year Plan (1951 - 1956) was based on the Harrod-Domar model, and focused on sectors like agriculture, price stability, power, and transport to address food shortages and promote economic growth. The Mahalanobis model, focused on industrialization, was introduced in the Second Five-Year Plan (1956 - 1961).

question: Which of the following years were considered plan holidays in Independent India? SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: 1966-1969. This period was a gap between the Third Five-Year Plan (1961-1966) and the Fourth Five-Year Plan (1969-1974). During this time, there was no formal five-year plan, and the government focused on annual plans to address the economic challenges faced by the country.

question: Which of the following options is INCORRECT? SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (1st shift)

options.C: i-b, ii-c, iii-d, iv-a (d) i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b

LPG policies: The Liberalization, Privatization, and Globalization reforms were introduced in 1991, during the Eighth Five-Year Plan (1992-1997). Rolling Plan: The Rolling Plan was introduced during the Janata Party government in the period 1978-80. Growth with justice and equity: This was a theme of the Ninth Five - Year Plan (1997-2002).

question: Which of the following is NOT one of the four primary explicit goals of five-year plans? SSC CPO 27/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Education. The model of the Indian Economy was premised on the concept of planning based on five year plans from 1951-2017. Plan and Aim/Goal : First Plan (Economic development), Second Plan (Rapid industrialization - heavy & basic industries), Third Plan (‘Self-reliant' and ‘self-generating' economy), Fourth Plan (Growth with stability and progressive achievement of self reliance), Fifth Plan (Removal of poverty' and 'attainment of self reliance').

question: Which Five Year Plan period saw the initiation of the Hill Area Development Programme? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (2nd shift)

The Planning Commission, which formulated and regulated these plans, was established on March 15, 1950, and replaced by NITI Aayog in 2015.

question: Growth, as envisaged in the five-year plans, refers to: SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

options.C: improvement in the level of education

India launched a series of FYP after independence to build its economy and attain development. The FYP was formulated, implemented and regulated by the Planning Commission, and was replaced by a think tank called NITI AAYOG in 2015.

question: Which industrial policy marked the beginning of liberalisation in the Indian industry, reducing the restrictions on private companies? SSC CGL 24/09/2024 (3rd Shift)

question: _____is defined as excess of total expenditure over total receipts excluding borrowings during a fiscal year. SSC CHSL 04/07/2024 (3rd shift)

The gross fiscal deficit is a key variable in judging the financial health of the public sector and the stability of the economy. Gross Primary Deficit is the fiscal deficit minus interest payments on previous borrowings.

question: Intervention by the monetary authority of a country in the money market to keep money supply stable against exogenous or sometimes external shocks is called _____. SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Sterilisation. It refers to the actions taken by a monetary authority, such as a central bank, to offset the effects of foreign exchange operations on the domestic money supply. For instance, if a central bank experiences an inflow of foreign exchange, it might conduct an open market sale of government securities to absorb the excess money and maintain the stability of the money supply. This process helps to protect the economy from external shocks and prevent inflationary or deflationary pressures.

question: What is the impact of proportional taxes? SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (3rd shift)

Marginal propensity to consume (MPC) is the fraction of additional income that a person or household spends. When taxes increase, disposable income decreases, which in turn reduces the MPC.

The variable reserve ratio is a monetary policy tool that central banks use to control credit and the money supply in the economy. It's made up of two components: the Cash Reserve Ratio (CRR) and the Statutory Liquidity Ratio (SLR).

question: The RBI act provides for how many members in RBI Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) ? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: 6. The Reserve Bank of India Act, 1934 (RBI Act) has been amended by the Finance Act, 2016 to provide for a statutory and institutionalized framework for a MPC. MPC (Monetary Policy Committee) members: RBI Governor (chairperson), Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy, An officer of the Bank to be nominated by the Central Board, Three persons to be appointed by the central government.

question: Which deficit reflects the borrowing needs of the government? SSC MTS 14/09/2023 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: Fiscal deficit : The difference between total revenue and total expenditure of the government. Fiscal Deficit = Total expenditure of the government (Capital and Revenue expenditure) – Total income of the government (Revenue receipts + recovery of loans + other receipts).

question: What is the change in fiscal deficit if both the primary deficit and interest payments are doubled? SSC CHSL 03/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Increase by 100%. Primary deficit - It is defined as the fiscal deficit of the current year minus interest payments on previous borrowings.

question: Gross primary deficit is equal to ________. SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Gross Primary Deficit is Gross Fiscal Deficit less interest payments.

question: The general target of the monetary policy is to ensure ___________ . A) price stability in the economy B) greater tax collections for the government C) employment generation in the rural areas SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Only A. Monetary policy - Actions and strategies adopted by a central bank to control the money supply, interest rates, and credit availability in an economy, aiming to achieve stable prices and sustainable economic growth.

question: In which year did the Government of India bring FRBM (Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management) Act into effect ? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: 2004-05. The Fiscal Responsibility and Budget Management (FRBM) Act 2003 envisages the setting of limits on the Central government’s debt and deficit. The Centre and states are mandated to reduce their fiscal deficit to 3 percent of GDP.

question: ______refers to a method adopted by the Central Bank to persuade or convince the commercial banks to advance credit in the economic interest of the country. SSC MTS 17/05/2023 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Moral Suasion. Marginal Standing Facility (MSF): Facility under which scheduled commercial banks can borrow additional amounts under overnight facility by dipping in their 'Statutory Liquidity Ratio' (SLR) portfolio up to a certain limit.

question: Who chairs the Monetary Policy Committee in India? SSC MTS 14/06/2023 (Evening)

solution.correct_answer: D. Governor, Reserve Bank of India
solution.explanation: Governor, Reserve Bank of India. The Monetary Policy Committee (MPC) is a statutory body constituted as per Section 45ZB under the RBI Act of 1934 by the Central Government.It consists: - RBI Governor as its ex officio chairperson, Deputy Governor in charge of monetary policy, member ex officio, An officer of the Bank nominated by the Central Board as member ex officio, Three persons are appointed by the central government.

question: Which of the following combinations of tenors of Treasury bills issued by the Government of India is correct ? SSC CHSL 13/03/2023 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 91 days, 182 days, and 364 days. Treasury Bills are short-term financial instruments issued by the government to meet its expenditure.

question: The monetary policy instrument called 'bank rate' is aligned to ______. SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Marginal standing facility rate. It is a scheme launched by the RBI in 2011-12. Liquidity adjustment facility is a monetary policy tool used by the RBI in India through which it absorbs liquidity

question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the government securities in the economy? I. It is a tradable instrument issued by the Central Government or the State Governments. II. They are called risk-free gilt-edged instruments. SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (4th Shift)

options.A: Neither I nor II (b) Only I

solution.explanation: Both I and II. A Government Security (G-Sec) is a tradable instrument issued by the Central Government or the State Governments. It acknowledges the Government’s debt obligation. G-Secs carry practically no risk of default and, hence, are called risk-free gilt-edged instruments.

question: Who is the Chairman of Financial Stability and Development Council (FSDC) of India? SSC MTS 14/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Finance Minister. Financial Stability and Development Council (FSDC) is a non-statutory apex council under the Ministry of Finance constituted by the Executive Order in 2010. Raghuram Rajan committee (2008) proposed its creation. It is chaired by the Finance Minister and its sub-committee is headed by the Governor of RBI.

question: When the government resorts to borrowing only to clear the backlog if interest payments, it is referred to as : SSC CHSL 25/05/2022 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Zero primary deficit. Miscellaneous

question: The Companies Act, ____ is an Act to consolidate and amend the law relating to companies. SSC Stenographer 11/12/2024 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 2013. The Companies Act, 2013 is divided into 29 chapters, 470 sections, and 7 schedules. The Act enables the Central Government (Ministry of Corporate Affairs) to make rules through subordinate legislation. The Act also explains the process of forming a company, including the name, charter, members, purpose, and share capital.

question: Match the following microfinance concepts with their descriptions. List I (Concepts) List II (Descriptions)

solution.explanation: a-(iv), b-(i), c-(ii), d-(iii).

question: Which among the following data was used to compute the estimates in the national Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) Baseline Report? SSC MTS 23/10/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: National Family Health Survey (NFHS-4). National Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) is a tool that measures poverty in India in multiple dimensions, beyond income. The MPI is developed by NITI Aayog in collaboration with the United Nations Development Programme (UNDP) and the Oxford Poverty and Human Development Initiative (OPHI).

question: Before the introduction of Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS), what type of surveys did the National Statistical Office (NSO) conduct for employment and unemployment indicators in India? SSC MTS 05/11/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Quinquennial surveys. Before the introduction of the Periodic Labour Force Survey (PLFS), the National Statistical Office (NSO) conducted quinquennial surveys under the National Sample Survey (NSS) program to collect employment and unemployment data. These surveys, conducted every five years, provided detailed insights into labor force participation and unemployment trends. The first such survey was conducted in 1972–73 during the 27th round of the NSS.

question: A famous organisation Self-Employed Women’s Association (SEWA) is related with which of the following states? SSC MTS 12/11/2024 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Gujarat. Self-Employed Women’s Association (SEWA) is a trade union based in Gujarat, founded in 1972 by Ela Bhatt.

question: What is the empirically fitted relationship between the rate of change of money, wage, and rate of unemployment known as ? SSC CGL 13/09/2024 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: Phillips curve states that inflation and unemployment have an inverse relationship; higher inflation is associated with lower unemployment and vice versa. This concept was first proposed by Alban William Phillips. Friedman’s model: Milton Friedman's monetary policy model, focusing on monetary supply and demand. Keynesian model: John Maynard Keynes' macroeconomic model, emphasizing government intervention and aggregate demand. Baumol hypothesis: William Baumol's theory on the relationship between inflation and economic growth.

question: Match the following items. List I List II i. Global System of Trade Preferences a. 2021 ii. India-Gulf Cooperation Council Free Trade Agreement b. 1988 iii. The India-Republic of Korea Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement c. 2004 iv. 7th Trade Policy Review d. 2010 www.ssccglpinnacle.com Download Pinnacle Exam Preparation App Search on TG: @apna_pdf Pinnacle Economics SSC CGL 17/09/2024 (1st Shift)

solution.explanation: i (b), ii (c), iii (d), iv (a). Global System of Trade Preferences (1988) - Promotes trade among developing countries. India-Gulf Cooperation Council Free Trade Agreement (2004) - Aims to liberalize trade relations and explore a Free Trade Agreement. India-Republic of Korea Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (2010) - Enhances economic cooperation by reducing tariffs on goods. 7th Trade Policy Review (2021) - A WTO mechanism for regularly reviewing member countries' trade policies.

question: During 2015, in ______ sector, Government of India had allowed about 49% of FDI. SSC CHSL 05/07/2024 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: defense. FDI Policy Reforms in sectors listed under Make in India since May 2014-15 : India has liberalized FDI policies in various sectors including food retail, rail infrastructure, construction, and manufacturing, allowing up to 100% foreign investment to boost economic growth and job creation.

question: Which of the following statements is/are true with respect to MRTP Act ? i) The Monopolies and Restrictive Trade Practices Act (MRTP Act) was repealed and replaced by the Competition Act, 2002. ii) The asset limit for MRTP companies was fixed at Rs. 25 crores by the first/original Monopolies and Restrictive Trade Practices Act (MRTP Act). iii) The Monopolies and Restrictive Trade Practices Act (MRTP Act) was first passed in 1969. SSC CHSL 08/07/2024 (2nd shift)

solution.explanation: Only i and iii. The MRTP Act was indeed first passed in 1969 and was later repealed and replaced by the Competition Act, 2002 . However, the asset limit for MRTP companies was fixed at Rs. 100 crores.

question: In 1955, _____noted the possibility of using small-scale industries for promoting rural development. SSC CHSL 09/07/2024 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: Karve Committee. Other committees are: Kelkar Committee - It was formed in 2002 under the chairmanship of Vijay Kelkar. The Kelkar Committee was re-constituted in 2015 to study and evaluate the Public Private Partnership (PPP) model in India. Sarkaria Committee (1983) formed under the chairmanship of Justice R.S. Sarkaria to review the question of center-state relations. The S. Chakravarty Committee (1982) was set up to review the working of the monetary system.

question: Match the items in List I with those in List II. List I List II i. Balanced Growth Theory a. Rosenstein Rodan ii. Big Push Theory b. Feldman- Mahalanobis iii. Secular Deterioration c. Ragnar Nurkse iv. Capital Goods and Heavy Industry d. Prebisch-Singer SSC CHSL 10/07/2024 (2nd shift)

options.A: i-c, ii-d, iii-a, iv-b (b) i-a, ii-b, iii-d, iv-c
options.C: i-c, ii-a, iii-d, iv-b (d) i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-c

solution.correct_answer: C. i-c, ii-a, iii-d, iv-b (d) i-d, ii-a, iii-b, iv-c
solution.explanation: i-c, ii-a, iii-d, iv-b. The doctrine of balanced growth states that there should be balanced growth of all sectors of the economy simultaneously. The Big Push theory is a development economics concept that suggests a large, coordinated investment in key areas can lead to sustained economic growth. Capital Goods refer to products that are used in the production of other products but are not incorporated into the new product.

question: In which year was the Foreign Investment Promotion Board established ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: 1968. The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB), housed in the Department of Economic Affairs, Ministry of Finance, is an inter-ministerial body, responsible for processing of FDI proposals and making recommendations for Government approval. In 1996, it was transferred to the Department for Promotion of Industry and Internal Trade (DPIIT) in the Ministry of Commerce and Industry. The Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) was replaced by the Foreign Investment Facilitation Portal (FIFP) in May 2017.

question: What was the main purpose of establishing the Agricultural Prices Commission in 1965 ? SSC CPO 28/06/2024 (3rd shift)

options.A: To determine the prices for various
options.B: To determine the price of seeds used
options.C: To determine the prices for various
options.D: To determine the price of fertiliser

solution.correct_answer: A. To determine the prices for various
solution.explanation: The Commission for Agricultural Costs and Prices (CACP) is an attached office under the Ministry of Agriculture & Farmers Welfare, Government of India, that recommends Minimum Support Prices (MSPs) for select crops. It was established in 1965 as the Agricultural Prices Commission, and was given its present name in 1985.

question: For which of the following sources of financial resources may financial intermediation NOT be required? SSC CPO 29/06/2024 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Family funds. Financial intermediation refers to the process where financial institutions act as intermediaries between savers and borrowers, facilitating the flow of funds. Raising equity through public offerings, borrowing from banks, and obtaining funds from All India Development Financial Institutions all involve financial intermediation. Banks itself acts as intermediaries between depositors and borrowers.

question: Which organisation in India holds the responsibility for setting the maximum residue limits (MRLs) of pesticides in food materials? SSC CHSL Tier II 10/01/2024

solution.correct_answer: B. Food Safety and Standards Authority
solution.explanation: (FSSAI) - It is an autonomous statutory body established under the Food Safety and Standards Act, 2006. It comes under the Administrative control of the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare. Headquarter - New Delhi.

question: What is the name of the Comprehensive Household Survey providing labour force statistics in India, which was first conducted in 1955 ? SSC CPO 04/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Employment-Unemployment Survey (EUS). It was first conducted in the 9th round of the National Sample Survey (NSS) in 1955. The current format of quinquennial (every 5 years) surveys started in the 27th round in 1972-73, based on the M. L. Dantwala Committee Report.

question: When was the 8th round of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT), the so-called 'Uruguay Round' which led to the establishment of World Trade Organization (WTO) completed ? SSC CPO 05/10/2023 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 1994. The General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) was signed in Geneva in 1947 by 23 countries, entered into force on 1 January 1948. The Uruguay Round of Conference (1987 to 1994), culminated in the Marrakesh Agreement, which led to the establishment of the World Trade Organization (1 January 1995).

question: ____ is the one organisation which is representing the entire cooperative movement in India. SSC CHSL 04/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: NCUI (National Cooperative Union of India) : Establishment - 1929, Headquarters - New Delhi. The Cooperation Ministry was formed on 6 July 2021. First Cooperation minister - Amit Shah. The National Federation of Cooperative Sugar Factories Limited (NFCSF) Founded in 1960.

question: Which organization formerly known as the Imperial Council of Agricultural Research and founded on July 16, 1929, is in charge of Agricultural Research and Education in India? SSC CHSL 07/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) : Autonomous organization under the Department of Agricultural Research and Education (DARE), Ministry of Agriculture and Farmers Welfare, Government of India. Headquarter : New Delhi.

question: Who said 'PURA is one of the mechanisms which will be utilized for transforming our villages into productive economic zones'? SSC CHSL 08/08/2023 (1st shift)

solution.explanation: APJ Abdul Kalam. PURA (Provision of Urban Amenities to Rural Areas). Objective : Provision of livelihood opportunities and urban amenities in rural areas to bridge the rural - urban divide.

question: Which of the following is NOT an approach for measuring unemployment in India? SSC CHSL 17/08/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Monthly Status Approach. Unemployment rate = (Unemployed Workers/Total labour force) × 100. The National Sample Survey Organization (NSSO) defines employment and unemployment.

question: Which of the following Acts was introduced to regulate Foreign Exchange in India in 1973 ? SSC CGL 14/07/2023 (4th shift)

solution.explanation: FERA (Foreign Exchange Regulation Act) - It came into effect on 01 January 1974. This act was passed to regulate and monitor foreign securities and exchange transactions. It was repealed and replaced by a new law - the Foreign Exchange Management Act, 1999 (FEMA) with effect from June 1, 2000.

question: A Plan of Economic Development for India' is also known as________ SSC CGL 21/07/2023 (3rd shift)

solution.explanation: Bombay Plan - Proposed by eight leading Indian industrialists and technocrats (J.R.D. Tata, Ghanshyam Das Birla, Ardeshir Dalal, Lala Shri Ram, Kasturbhai Lalbhai, Ardeshir Darabshaw Shroff, Sir Purshottamdas Thakurdas and John Mathai). It was published in two parts : The first volume was released in 1944 and the second in 1945.

question: Which of the following statements is correct? I. Death rate in India is 7.2 per 1000 in 2011. II. Life expectancy at birth is 72.6 years in 2012. SSC CHSL 16/03/2023 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Only I. Life expectancy at birth has increased from 36.7 years in 1951 to 67.9 years in 2012. The birth rate in a period is the total number of live births per 1,000 population divided by the length of the period in years.

question: In India, which of the following statements is true about the National Investment Fund? Statements: I. It was created in 2005. II. 75% of its annual income was to be used for schemes promoting health, education and employment. III. It was dissolved in 2018. SSC CGL Tier II (02/03/2023)

solution.correct_answer: D. Only statements I and II
solution.explanation: Government constituted the National Investment Fund (NIF) in November 2005 into which the proceeds from disinvestment of Central Public Sector Enterprises were to be channelized. The corpus of the National Investment Fund will be of a permanent nature .

question: Joint Liability Group is usually an informal group that consists of _________ individuals who seek loans against mutual guarantee. SSC CGL 08/12/ 2022 (2nd Shift)

solution.explanation: 4-10. The loans are usually taken for agricultural purposes or associated activities. JLG is a credit oriented group whereas Self help group is a savings oriented group.

question: Who released a special stamp entitled ‘Wheat Revolution’ in July 1968 ? SSC CGL 13/12/2022 (3rd Shift)

solution.explanation: Indira Gandhi. The Wheat Revolution (Green Revolution) was initiated in the 1960s {under the Third Five Year Plan (1961-66)} by introducing high-yielding varieties of rice and wheat.

question: Which of the following shows modernization to increase the production of goods and Services ? SSC CPO 09/11/2022 (Afternoon)

options.A: Adoption of old technique with large

solution.explanation: Adoption of new technology. Technology adoption refers to the process of accepting, integrating, and using new technology in society.

question: The Bankruptcy Legislative Reforms Committee (BLRC) was set up in which of the following years? SSC CPO 11/11/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: 2014. Chairman of the committee - Dr. T. K. Viswanathan. Other Facts - The Insolvency and Bankruptcy Board of India (IBBI) was established in 2016. .

question: Bhagwati Committee (1973) presented a report on ____________. SSC MTS 20/07/2022 (Morning)

solution.explanation: Unemployment and Public Welfare. Upon recommendations of the Dantwala Committee, 3 approaches are used for measurement of unemployment in India, such as Usual Status Approach, Weekly Status Approach, and Daily Status Approach.

question: Which classical economist popularised the following phrase: "From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs” ? SSC MTS 20/10/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Karl Marx popularised the following phrase: "From each according to his ability, to each according to his needs”. He is famous for his theories about capitalism and communism. Famous work - "The Communist Manifesto" (Written by Karl Marx and Friedrich Engels), "Das Kapital".

question: Which economist took the subject of economics away from approaches that focus exclusively on income, growth, and utility, with an increased emphasis on individual entitlements, capabilities, freedoms, and rights? SSC MTS 02/11/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Amartya Sen is famous for his significant contributions to welfare economics (for which he was awarded the 1998 Nobel Prize in economics).

question: What is the objective of the 'Doughnut Model' of development ? SSC CGL 16/08/2021 (Morning)

options.C: It envisions rapid development at an
options.D: It envisions a world in which people

solution.correct_answer: D. It envisions a world in which people
solution.explanation: The Doughnut model of economics was proposed by Kate Raworth.

question: According to Malthusian theory, which of the following grows in geometric progression? SSC CGL 18/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: Population. This theory, proposed by Malthus who stated that the human population increases geometrically, while food production increases arithmetically.

question: What are the two variables whose relationship is given by the environmental Kuznets curve? SSC CGL 23/08/2021 (Evening)

solution.explanation: The environmental Kuznets curve depicts the relationship between environmental degradation and per capita income.

question: Which economic thought talks about methodological individualism or the idea that people will act in meaningful ways which can be analyzed ? SSC CHSL 13/04/2021 (Afternoon)

solution.explanation: Austrian economic thought. This doctrine was introduced as a methodological precept for the social sciences by Max Weber.
